population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: To determine whether combining behavioral urinary incontinence treatments with physical activity (150 minutes of weekly walking and twice-weekly strength training) improves urinary incontinence in frail older women.
results_summary: The treatment group reported a 50% reduction in daily leaks, while the control group reported no change. The treatment group also showed significant improvement in urine leakage and overall UI improvement compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Frail older women (mean age 84.9 ± 6.4) without dementia.
effective_dosage: 150 minutes of weekly walking and twice-weekly strength training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity and reliability of spatio-temporal gait parameters measured by GaitRite in motor incomplete spinal cord-injured (SCI) patients.
results_summary: GaitRite was found to be a valid and reliable tool for measuring gait characteristics in SCI patients, with precision and sensitivity approximately three times better than clinical tests. Higher gait velocity correlated with greater independence, lower use of walking aids, better motor performance, and improved gait mobility.
population_specificity: 23 motor subacute and chronic incomplete SCI patients (AIS D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a 12-week supervised exercise intervention on physical function and body composition in bariatric surgery patients 12-24 months post-surgery.
results_summary: The exercise group showed significant improvements in walking ability (ISWT), body composition, physical function, and cardiovascular measures at 12 weeks, with further gains at 24 weeks. A 5.6 kg difference in body mass favored the exercise group over controls by 24 weeks.
population_specificity: Inactive adult bariatric surgery patients with BMI ≥30 kg/m², 12-24 months post-surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (supervised exercise intervention, details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the connections between obesity and transportation choices, particularly walking, to inform potential public health interventions.
results_summary: The study suggests that commuting by public transit may serve as an effective intervention for obesity, and new data-gathering tools could improve future research on transportation-related physical activity.
population_specificity: General population in the USA (national obesity rates referenced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Internet-delivered, physiotherapist-prescribed home exercise and pain-coping skills training (PCST) for managing chronic knee pain.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in pain during walking and physical function at 3 months, with sustained benefits at 9 months, compared to the control group. Secondary outcomes, including quality of life and self-efficacy, also improved significantly in the intervention group.
population_specificity: 148 persons aged 50 years or older with chronic knee pain.
effective_dosage: 7 videoconferencing sessions with a physiotherapist for home exercise and a PCST program over 3 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a weight loss maintenance program, including self-reported walking and moderate physical activity, compared to usual care in obese adults.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in secondary outcomes, including walking and moderate physical activity, at 56 weeks between the intervention and usual care groups.
population_specificity: Obese outpatients (BMI ≥30 kg/m²) who lost at least 4 kg during a 16-week weight loss program, primarily middle-aged white men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) versus conventional therapy (CT) on gait speed, mobility, balance, fatigue, and quality of life in progressive MS patients, while also exploring neural plasticity biomarkers.
results_summary: The study expects RAGT to improve mobility compared to CT in progressive MS patients, with additional analysis of clinical and circulating biomarkers to assess neural plasticity changes.
population_specificity: Progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) patients with EDSS scale scores of 6-7.
effective_dosage: Twelve 2-hour training sessions over a 4-week period (three sessions/week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a 12-week Nordic Walking training program on the perceived pain threshold and flexibility of selected upper-body muscle groups in postmenopausal female office workers.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in the perceived pain threshold in the upper trapezius, mid trapezius, latissimus dorsi, and infraspinatus muscles, as well as improved shoulder mobility in the Nordic Walking group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal female office workers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of plasma exchange on recovery outcomes, including walking ability, in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS).
results_summary: Plasma exchange significantly improved walking recovery times and disability grades compared to supportive care, with moderate-quality evidence supporting its efficacy. However, it also increased the risk of relapse within the first year, though long-term muscle strength recovery was better.
population_specificity: Adults with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), including severely and mildly affected participants.
effective_dosage: Not specified (plasma exchange regimens varied by study).
study_duration: Varied by study, with follow-up assessments up to one year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and acceptability of four endothelin receptor antagonists (ERAs) for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) patients, focusing on 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and clinical worsening.
results_summary: All four PAH therapies significantly increased 6MWD compared to placebo, with bosentan and ambrisentan also reducing the risk of clinical worsening. Ambrisentan was the only therapy associated with a decreased risk of all-cause discontinuation, but no significant differences were found between the therapies.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) (total n=2172).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, hemodynamic effects, and functional outcomes of percutaneous ventricular restoration using a ventricular partitioning device (VPD) in heart failure patients with severely reduced LV ejection fraction.
results_summary: The study found that VPD implantation improved hemodynamics (reduced LV volumes, increased LV ejection fraction) and functional status (increased 6-min walking distance and quality of life scores) with a >90% procedural success rate. Optimal implant position was crucial for good clinical outcomes, but more durable devices with long-lasting effects are needed.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize qualitative studies on compassion fatigue in nursing to understand its impact and identify measures to mitigate it.
results_summary: The study identified four themes related to compassion fatigue: physical and emotional symptoms, triggering factors, and preventive measures. It highlighted the relevance of compassion fatigue in nursing and proposed a theoretical model for future research and clinical practice.
population_specificity: Nurses working in overburdened healthcare systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of a novel implant (Y-STRUT) combined with bone cement for treating lytic lesions of the proximal femur in patients with metastatic bone disease.
results_summary: The study found that the procedure was feasible and safe, with no reported cases of wound infection, bleeding, leakage, or inflammation. Additionally, 86% of patients could resume walking at hospital discharge, and there were improvements in pain levels (VAS decreased from 3.6 to 1.3) and functional outcomes (OHS-12 score increased from 30 to 37) at 1-year follow-up.
population_specificity: Ten patients (average age 62 years, 67% male) with pertrochanteric lytic lesions and an average Mirels' score of 9.42.
effective_dosage: 9.2 ± 3.1 ml of bone cement injected during the procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a multicomponent exercise program, including walking retraining, could prevent functional and cognitive decline in institutionalized older adults.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it is designed to assess changes in functionality, frailty, cognitive status, and biological markers over a 6-month intervention period. Results will guide clinical practice for managing institutionalized elders.
population_specificity: Institutionalized older adults aged ≥70 years, capable of standing and walking independently for 10 meters, with a Barthel Index ≥50 and MEC-35 ≥20.
effective_dosage: Not specified (multicomponent exercise program, including walking retraining).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of using an immersive VR head-mounted display (HMD) for extended walking sessions in older adults and individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: Most participants completed the trials without discomfort, with no significant changes in simulator sickness symptoms or balance measures. Stress decreased in all groups, and arousal increased in the PD group after VR exposure.
population_specificity: Healthy young adults, healthy older adults, and individuals with Parkinson's disease (11 participants per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of strength, agility, and secondary prevention (SAP) treatment versus SAP plus perturbation training (SAP+PERT) on gait mechanics and the elimination of gait asymmetries in men 1 and 2 years after ACL reconstruction.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between SAP and SAP+PERT groups in gait mechanics or the elimination of gait asymmetries. Gait asymmetries persisted in both groups at 1 and 2 years postoperatively, indicating neither intervention effectively restored interlimb symmetry.
population_specificity: Athletic male patients who underwent ACL reconstruction and met specific postoperative criteria (e.g., ≥ 80% quadriceps strength symmetry, minimal knee effusion, full ROM, no pain, completion of a running progression).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated; follow-up assessments occurred at 1 and 2 years postoperatively.

study_goal: To compare the medium-term efficacy of gait training using a single-leg version of the Hybrid Assistive Limb® (HAL®) on the paretic side with conventional gait training (CGT) in recovery-phase stroke patients.
results_summary: The HAL® group showed significant improvement in Functional Ambulation Category (FAC) after 12 sessions and at 8 and 12 weeks compared to the conventional group, suggesting HAL® may improve independent walking more efficiently than CGT at 1 and 2 months post-intervention.
population_specificity: Post-stroke participants (n=24) in the recovery phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding load to the non-paretic lower limb during treadmill training influences cardiovascular parameters and gait performance in subacute stroke patients.
results_summary: Both groups (with and without load addition) showed improved gait speed and walking distance, but cardiovascular parameters remained unchanged. No differences were observed between the groups in any session.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with gait deficits (n=38).
effective_dosage: Treadmill training with a mass attached to the non-paretic lower limb (experimental group) vs. treadmill training alone (control group), 9 sessions over 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether spatiotemporal variables and asymmetry ratios could serve as mechanistic recovery measures in physical therapy interventions for post-stroke walking rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that spatiotemporal variables describe gait deviations but may not independently indicate functional recovery, while asymmetry measures provide additional insights into coordinative requirements and potential recovery. The review included 46 studies, with varying interventions showing statistically significant changes in walking speed.
population_specificity: Post-stroke patients undergoing physical therapy interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the neurological manifestations associated with Ehlers-Danlos syndromes (EDS), including their impact on mobility and daily activities such as walking.
results_summary: The study found that EDS patients experience neuromuscular symptoms like weakness, myalgia, easy fatigability, and limited walking, which impair mobility and daily activities. Spinal instability and musculoskeletal pain further exacerbate these limitations.
population_specificity: Patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndromes (EDS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of moderate physical activity, including walking, on tertiary physical performance outcomes in older adults at risk for mobility disability.
results_summary: The study found that physical activity, including walking, significantly improved total SPPB score and chair-stand performance compared to health education, with 400 m walking speed also being faster in the PA group. Changes in chair-stand performance explained a considerable portion of the reduction in major mobility disability.
population_specificity: 1635 older adults (aged 78.9 ± 5.2 years, 67.2% women) at risk for mobility disability (SPPB <10).
effective_dosage: Moderate physical activity including walking, resistance, and balance training (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of a home-based cardiac rehabilitation program involving walking with mixed surveillance versus traditional hospital-based rehabilitation in patients with ischemic heart disease at moderate cardiovascular risk.
results_summary: The home-based walking program was found to be as effective and safe as traditional hospital-based rehabilitation, with no significant differences in exercise capacity or cardiovascular complications, though hospital-based programs showed better improvements in quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with stable coronary artery disease at moderate cardiovascular risk.
effective_dosage: Walking at 70% of heart rate reserve for the first month and 80% for the second month, 1 hour per day, 5-7 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of adding trimetazidine (TMZ) to background antianginal therapy on angina frequency, nitrate use, exercise capacity, and well-being in a real-world clinical setting.
results_summary: Add-on TMZ significantly reduced angina frequency and short-acting nitrate use within 2 weeks, maintained effects over 6 months, improved walking distance and well-being, and was well tolerated.
population_specificity: 896 patients (54% women, aged 29-90 years, 42.6% >65 years, 63% with class II angina) receiving beta-blockers alone or in combination.
effective_dosage: TMZ modified release 35 mg twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in mechanistic gait outcomes and describe motor recovery using laboratory-based variables in stroke rehabilitation trials.
results_summary: The review found no consistent set of outcome measures to mechanistically explain changes in walking speed, and no theoretical basis for selecting independent outcome measures. Various interventions showed mixed results, but no causal link between mechanistic variables and functional gains was established.
population_specificity: Stroke rehabilitation patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of 4R programs (reablement, reactivation, rehabilitation, and restorative) on older adults receiving home care services, including outcomes related to functional abilities and walking impairments.
results_summary: The study found that 4R interventions showed promise in improving functional abilities and reducing health care service usage, with statistically significant outcomes in these areas, though generalizability and intervention details were limited.
population_specificity: Older adults receiving home care services, including those discharged from hospital wards and those without recent hospital stays.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between gait variability and falls in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) with moderate disability.
results_summary: The study found that PwMS classified as fallers had significantly higher gait variability in step length and single support compared to non-fallers. Gait variability scores were also strongly correlated with clinical walking tests, particularly step length variability.
population_specificity: 91 people with multiple sclerosis (50 women) with an expanded disability status scale score of 4.0 and 4.5.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of exclusive robot-assisted end-effector-based gait training for gait recovery in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in global motor performance, gait endurance, balance, coordination, lower limb strength, and spasticity in chronic stroke patients undergoing robot-assisted gait training. Significant percentages of patients achieved clinically meaningful improvements in specific tests (6 Minute Walk Test and Timed Up and Go test) depending on their Functional Ambulation Classification group.
population_specificity: Chronic post-stroke patients (n=100) divided into two groups based on Functional Ambulation Classification (FAC <3 and FAC ≥3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine gait adaptations in Parkinson's disease (PD) and healthy subjects during positive pressure body weight-supported treadmill training (BWSTT) and post-intervention overground walking.
results_summary: During BWSTT, healthy subjects showed significant increases in step length and decreases in cadence, while PD subjects did not. Post-intervention, both groups exhibited significant improvements in velocity and cadence during overground walking.
population_specificity: Ten PD patients and ten healthy individuals.
effective_dosage: 10-min progressive BWSTT trial from 10% to 40% body weight support.
study_duration: Single session with post-intervention assessments at 5, 10, and 15 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ectopic fat accumulation in COPD patients is associated with clinical outcomes, including 6-minute walking distance (6MWD).
results_summary: The study found that increased ectopic fat accumulation in COPD patients was associated with poorer clinical outcomes, including reduced 6MWD. However, the abstract does not provide detailed statistical results or effect sizes for walking performance.
population_specificity: 585 subjects with COPD from the ECLIPSE cohort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify physical activity levels after lumbar surgery and identify spine-related variables associated with not meeting recommended activity thresholds, including walking.
results_summary: Only 35% of patients met the ≥1400 kcal/week threshold, and 26% met the ≥150 minutes/week threshold. Not meeting these thresholds was associated with revision surgery, multilevel surgery, degenerative diagnoses, subsequent spine surgery, and more postoperative back pain.
population_specificity: 422 patients (mean age 57, 55% men, 80% with degenerative diagnoses, 63% with multilevel surgery) who underwent lumbar surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) in examining gait disorders in neurological patients and its potential clinical applications.
results_summary: The study found that oxy-hemoglobin levels in the prefrontal and premotor cortices are sensitive to compensation strategies for gait disorders, suggesting fNIRS could be valuable for clinical assessment and rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Neurological patients with gait disorders (e.g., Parkinson's disease, stroke).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a community-based walking intervention to enhance quality of life in people with recurrent/metastatic cancer.
results_summary: The intervention was acceptable and well-tolerated, with exercise being popular and conveying benefits to participants, though recruitment was lower than anticipated and attrition was high (45% by week 24). Most patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) were acceptable but not sensitive to change.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced breast, prostate, gynaecological, or haematological cancers.
effective_dosage: Walk for at least 30 minutes on alternate days and attend a volunteer-led group walk weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily cane use for 12 weeks reduces medial tibiofemoral bone marrow lesion volume and improves pain, function, and quality of life in people with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study will investigate the effects of cane use on disease progression and clinical symptoms, but results are not yet available as it is a planned randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: People aged 50+ with medial tibiofemoral osteoarthritis and at least one medial tibiofemoral bone marrow lesion, excluding morbidly obese individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of a novel stem cell-based medicinal product (Cartistem) for regenerating articular cartilage in osteoarthritic knees.
results_summary: The study found improved cartilage repair, reduced pain (VAS scores), and stable clinical outcomes over 7 years, with no severe adverse events or cases of osteogenesis/tumorigenesis.
population_specificity: Patients with Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 osteoarthritis and ICRS grade 4 cartilage defects (n=7).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the hemodynamic effects of riociguat in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), not Walking.
results_summary: The study found that riociguat significantly improved hemodynamic parameters, such as reducing pulmonary vascular resistance, in both treatment-naïve and pre-treated PAH patients.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), either treatment-naïve or pre-treated with endothelin receptor antagonists or non-intravenous prostanoids.
effective_dosage: Riociguat up to 2.5 mg three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of robotic-assisted gait training therapy (RAGT) on dynamic equilibrium control during walking in children with Cerebral Palsy (CP).
results_summary: The study found that RAGT, based on intensity and repetition of movement, had beneficial effects on recovery and improvement of postural and locomotor functions in children with CP, particularly in dynamic equilibrium control during walking.
population_specificity: Children with Cerebral Palsy (CP)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of autologous bone marrow-derived ALDHbr cells in improving walking ability (peak walking time) and physiological outcomes in patients with peripheral artery disease and claudication.
results_summary: The study found that ALDHbr cell administration did not improve peak walking time or magnetic resonance imaging outcomes, and changes in walking time were not associated with anatomical or physiological improvements.
population_specificity: 78 patients (57 male, 21 female; mean age 66±9 years) with claudication and infrainguinal peripheral artery disease.
effective_dosage: 10 injections into the thigh and calf of the index leg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-week combined exercise intervention (aerobic, resistance, and inspiratory muscle training) on muscle power and functional variables in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.
results_summary: The exercise intervention significantly improved leg/bench press power, five-repetition sit-to-stand test performance, maximal inspiratory pressure, and peak oxygen uptake, with no major adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (n=40, 60% women, mean age ~45-46 years, including 10% with chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension).
effective_dosage: Five aerobic, three resistance, and six inspiratory muscle training sessions per week (supervised in-hospital).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically evaluate the relationship between diet and frailty development and prevention, including the role of nutritional factors in frailty criteria such as walking speed.
results_summary: The abstract suggests an association between frailty and dietary factors, including protein, energy intake, and micronutrients, as well as healthy dietary patterns like the Mediterranean diet, but does not specifically report on walking outcomes.
population_specificity: Geriatric individuals with or at risk of frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if real-time visual feedback could modify biomechanical factors linked to elevated metabolic demand during walking in individuals with transtibial amputation.
results_summary: Visual feedback reduced center of mass sway (12%) and quadriceps activity (12%), but did not significantly affect metabolic rate or thigh muscle co-contraction. Heart rate increased with center-of-mass feedback, and metabolic rates remained similar to controls.
population_specificity: Eight individuals with unilateral, traumatic transtibial amputation and eight uninjured controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare hemodynamic responses (e.g., cardiac output, blood pressure) between light-intensity, blood-flow restricted (BFR), and high-intensity forms of resistance and aerobic exercise in the same participants.
results_summary: The study found that light-intensity exercise with BFR produced hemodynamic responses (e.g., systolic blood pressure) similar to high-intensity exercise and greater than light-intensity exercise without BFR, for both resistance (leg-press) and aerobic (treadmill) trials.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.
effective_dosage: Light-intensity bout (LI) followed by light-intensity bout with BFR (80% resting systolic blood pressure), then high-intensity bout (HI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify central nervous system changes in ACL patients compared to healthy controls during walking, jogging, and landing.
results_summary: ACL patients showed significant increases in delta, theta, alpha, and beta band EEG power during walking, jogging, and landing, along with EEG asymmetry in frontal and central-parietal areas, which extended during more complex movements.
population_specificity: ACL patients and healthy controls

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of exercise-based rehabilitation programs, including walking, for adults with atrial fibrillation or those treated for atrial fibrillation.
results_summary: The study found no clear difference in mortality or serious adverse events between exercise and no-exercise groups, but exercise-based rehabilitation improved exercise capacity, though the quality of evidence was moderate to very low.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18 years or older with atrial fibrillation or post-treatment for atrial fibrillation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied by trial, including aerobic exercise, resistance training, Qi-gong, and inspiratory muscle training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Ginkgo biloba extract (GBE) could improve gait stability in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) under single and dual-task walking conditions.
results_summary: After 6 months, GBE significantly improved dual-task-related cadence compared to placebo, with non-significant trends for gait velocity and stride time variability. The findings suggest GBE may enhance dual-task gait performance in MCI patients.
population_specificity: Patients aged 50-85 years with MCI and dual-task-related gait impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if daily-life gait assessments were more effective than clinical gait assessments at identifying fall risk in older adults.
results_summary: Daily-life gait assessments (lower gait endurance, higher within-walk variability) better distinguished fallers from non-fallers than clinical tests. These measures correlated with age, health, and functional decline.
population_specificity: Independent-living older adults (mean age 75.5 ± 7.8).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether regular light postprandial physical activity (such as walking) improves long-term blood glucose levels in individuals with hyperglycemia or at high risk of hyperglycemia.
results_summary: The study found no significant within- or between-group differences in glycemic variables despite increased physical activity in the intervention group. The intervention group reported higher daily activity levels, but this did not translate into measurable improvements in blood glucose control.
population_specificity: Individuals with hyperglycemia not using antidiabetics or at high risk for type 2 diabetes (n=56, with 40 completing the study).
effective_dosage: Minimum 30 minutes of daily light physical activity, starting within 30 minutes after a meal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether participant age, sex, and BMI influenced the effectiveness of brisk walking for obesity management in adults.
results_summary: Brisk walking led to clinically significant reductions in body weight, BMI, waist circumference, and fat mass for obese men and women under 50. Obese women over 50 achieved modest losses, but gains in fat-free mass reduced overall weight change.
population_specificity: Obese adults (men and women), with specific findings stratified by age (under and over 50) and sex.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional trajectory of drisapersen-treated subjects with Duchenne muscular dystrophy to a matched natural history cohort to assess the treatment's impact on walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that drisapersen-treated subjects showed better functional outcomes, with none of the "stable" subjects losing ambulation compared to matched natural history subjects, and a slower decline in rise from floor (RFF) for continuous ambulatory subjects.
population_specificity: Boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (12 treated with drisapersen, 75-79 in natural history cohort).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biomechanical efficacy, clinical effectiveness, cost-effectiveness, and workplace safety of compliant flooring systems for preventing fall-related injuries in healthcare settings.
results_summary: Compliant flooring reduced fall-related impact forces with minimal effects on balance but may increase fall risk; preliminary evidence suggests it could be cost-effective but may increase physical demands for healthcare workers.
population_specificity: Older adults in healthcare settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intensive blood pressure control affects changes in gait speed and mobility status in older adults with hypertension.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in gait speed decline or mobility limitation between intensive and standard blood pressure treatment groups. No subgroup differences were observed based on age, sex, race, or other factors.
population_specificity: Adults aged 75 years or older with hypertension and no history of type 2 diabetes or stroke.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (blood pressure targets: <120 mm Hg vs. <140 mm Hg).
study_duration: Median follow-up of 3 years (interquartile range: 2-3 years).

study_goal: The researchers were reviewing advancements in the evaluation and treatment of atypical community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), not Walking.
results_summary: The study did not investigate Walking; it focused on the causes, diagnostic challenges, and treatment of atypical CAP.
population_specificity: Patients with atypical community-acquired pneumonia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether botulinum toxin A (BoNT-A) injections in calf muscles reduce energy cost during walking, improve walking capacity, and enhance physical activity, pain, and self-perceived performance in children with spastic cerebral palsy.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results; the study was ongoing at the time of publication, with results expected by spring 2019.
population_specificity: Children aged 4–17.5 years with spastic cerebral palsy (Gross Motor Function Classification System levels I and II).
study_duration: Follow-up at 4, 12 (primary endpoint), and 24 weeks post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term safety, walking improvements, and changes in drug responsiveness of prolonged-release fampridine in patients with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in walking speed, endurance, and self-perceived ambulatory function with PR fampridine, persisting over long-term treatment. A notable proportion of patients showed enhanced responsiveness to the drug over time.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (PwMS) who completed the FAMPKIN core study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how high-intensity aerobic interval training (HAIT) affects risk factors associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D), specifically focusing on maximal oxygen uptake (VO₂ max).
results_summary: The study found that HAIT led to a 21% increase in VO₂ max and was effective in improving aerobic fitness and reducing risk factors associated with T2D.
population_specificity: Thirty-eight individuals with type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: HAIT consisted of 4 × 4 min of walking or running uphill at 85-95% of maximal heart rate; MIT involved continuous walking at 70-75% of maximal heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare baseline exercise capacity and changes after calcium channel blocker (CCB) or sildenafil therapy in patients with vasodilator-responsive idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (VR-IPAH) versus vasodilator-nonresponsive idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (VNR-IPAH).
results_summary: The study found that ventilatory efficiency was better in VR-IPAH patients compared to VNR-IPAH patients, and CCB therapy improved aerobic capacity and ventilatory efficiency during exercise in VR-IPAH patients.
population_specificity: Patients with newly diagnosed VR-IPAH and VNR-IPAH, matched for age, sex, and pulmonary vascular resistance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors influencing quality of life after lower limb amputation for peripheral arterial occlusive disease, focusing on the impact of walking with a prosthesis.
results_summary: The study found that successful prosthetic walking significantly improved quality of life, while factors like trans-femoral amputation, older age, male gender, longer time since amputation, and diabetes negatively affected it.
population_specificity: Individuals with lower limb amputations due to peripheral arterial occlusive disease, many of whom had diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the relevance of gait analysis under dual-task conditions in elderly people with gait disorders or memory impairment to evaluate severity, differentiate pathologies, and identify motor phenotypes.
results_summary: The study identified four clinical subgroups and five pathological subgroups, showing that dual-task gait analysis effectively differentiated severity and pathology types, with central nervous system pathologies and mild cognitive impairment exhibiting higher dual-task costs. Motor phenotypes were identified, though correlations with brain imaging require further study.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 76.3 ± 7.2, 56% women) with gait disorders or memory impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility of using wearable sensors to monitor gait-related balance exercise progression in individuals with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study successfully obtained training activity data in 98% of sessions, showing progressive increases in activity levels (28-43% of participants' daily activity). Most participants perceived the training as challenging, supporting the feasibility of wearable sensors for objective monitoring.
population_specificity: Individuals with Parkinson's disease (n=10).
effective_dosage: Three sessions/week of highly-challenging balance exercises, progressively increasing gait-related activities and dual-tasking time.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess differences in dropout rates and outcomes of pulmonary rehabilitation (PR) between COPD patients with and without acute exacerbations (AEs).
results_summary: Severe AEs were associated with higher dropout rates from PR, while mild-to-moderate AEs did not affect dropout or response. Completers with severe AEs showed deterioration in the 6-minute walk test (6MWT), whereas those without AEs or with mild-to-moderate AEs improved.
population_specificity: Clinically stable patients with moderate-to-very severe COPD (mean age 64.1 years, 55.6% male).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of a yearlong multicomponent rehabilitation program, including guidance for safe walking, on physical activity levels and their maintenance among older people recovering from a hip fracture.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased physical activity levels post-intervention and maintained the increase at 1-year follow-up, particularly in participants with higher baseline physical function (SPPB score ≥7).
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged ≥60 years recovering from a hip fracture (N=81).
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included progressive home exercise and PA counseling).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the mechanisms regulating macrophage death in atherosclerosis, including apoptosis, necroptosis, and efferocytosis, to identify therapeutic opportunities for plaque stability.
results_summary: The study found that macrophage necroptosis contributes to necrotic core formation and plaque instability, while preresolving mediators enhance efferocytosis and reduce plaque vulnerability. The "don't eat me" signal CD47 was also identified as impairing efferocytosis in atherosclerotic lesions.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on macrophage mechanisms in atherosclerosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a progressive muscle strengthening program using a Swiss ball for improving muscle strength and walking performance in patients with ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
results_summary: The intervention group showed statistically significant improvements in muscle strength (1 RM capacity), 6-minute walk test, timed up and go test, and Likert scale compared to the control group. No differences were observed in functional capacity evaluations (BASFI, HAQ-S, BASMI, SF-36, TUG, ASDAS, ESR, and CRP dosage).
population_specificity: Sixty patients with ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
effective_dosage: Eight exercises performed with free weights on a Swiss ball two times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether robotic-assisted gait training (RAGT) combined with a conventional exercise program (CEP) improves walking ability and motor function in patients with mild Parkinson's disease (PD) compared to standard gait training.
results_summary: The study found that RAGT significantly improved walking ability and motor function in PD patients, with effects lasting up to three months post-treatment. The experimental group showed better outcomes in the Tinetti Walking test and UPDRS-III motor score compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 38 patients with mild Parkinson's disease (Hoehn & Yahr stage 2-2.5).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of RAGT (using Lokomat device) plus 30 minutes of CEP for the experimental group; 30 minutes of conventional gait training plus 30 minutes of CEP for the control group.
study_duration: Treatment duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up assessments were conducted immediately after and 12 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of dalfampridine extended release (D-ER) in adults with cerebral palsy (CP) and limited ambulatory ability, and to explore its effects on sensorimotor function.
results_summary: The study found that D-ER was generally safe and well tolerated, with adverse events consistent with previous trials. However, no significant differences were observed between D-ER and placebo in functional outcomes, including walking speed, hand strength, or manual dexterity.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-70 with cerebral palsy and limited ambulatory ability (83% had spastic CP).
study_duration: 1 week of D-ER or placebo, followed by a 1-week washout and 1 week of the opposite treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and acceptability of a novel intervention combining exercise (including walking), health education, and group auditory rehabilitation to improve functional fitness, social connectedness, and health-related quality of life in older adults with hearing loss.
results_summary: The study proposed a 10-week intervention involving group walking and other exercises, but results were not yet available as it was a pilot trial to assess feasibility and preliminary effects. The abstract suggests the intervention could address functional fitness declines and psychosocial impacts of hearing loss.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults aged 65 years or older with self-reported hearing loss.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of group walking at a self-selected pace, twice a week for the intervention group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the pathophysiology of limb symptoms in peripheral artery disease (PAD) and identify potential mechanisms beyond arterial obstruction that contribute to walking impairment.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that limb symptoms in PAD, such as intermittent claudication and diminished walking ability, are influenced by factors beyond arterial obstruction, including inflammation, vascular dysfunction, and altered skeletal muscle function. Understanding these mechanisms could lead to novel therapies to improve functional capacity in PAD patients.
population_specificity: Adults with lower extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dalfampridine's beneficial effects on walking ability in MS patients also extended to other symptoms like cognition, fatigue, and depression.
results_summary: The study found that dalfampridine improved cognition, depression, and fatigue in MS patients, regardless of whether they were responders or nonresponders to mobility improvements. These effects were observed across the entire patient cohort.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and impaired mobility (34 participants, 22 responders, 12 nonresponders).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the development and effectiveness of Body Weight Support Treadmill Training as a rehabilitative approach to restore walking in spinal cord injury (SCI) patients.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the role of European physicians in advancing SCI medicine and introduces Body Weight Support Treadmill Training as an activity-based therapy for restoring walking in SCI patients. It also discusses variations in organizational systems and health policies affecting SCI rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Spinal cord injury (SCI) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a supported osteoarthritis self-management program influenced the proportion of patients reaching the recommended level of health-enhancing physical activity (HEPA) and how factors like BMI, gender, age, and comorbidity affected this outcome.
results_summary: The proportion of patients reaching HEPA increased from 77% to 82% at 3 months but declined to 76% at 12 months. Not reaching HEPA was associated with overweight, obesity, male gender, and severe osteoarthritis or other conditions affecting walking ability.
population_specificity: Patients with clinically verified hip or knee osteoarthritis in primary care (n=6810).
effective_dosage: At least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity per week (HEPA recommendation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of an arm sling on gait efficiency in hemiplegic stroke patients using walking aids.
results_summary: The study found that using an arm sling significantly improved walking endurance and reduced energy cost and oxygen expenditure in hemiplegic patients using a single cane. No significant effects were observed in the quad cane group.
population_specificity: Hemiplegic stroke patients with shoulder subluxation dependent on canes (single cane or quad cane).
study_duration: Same-day testing (6-minute Walk Test and 10-m Walk Test)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity of step count and heart rate measurements from five commercially available self-monitoring devices during walking tests.
results_summary: The study found varying levels of accuracy among the devices, with the Garmin Vivofit 2 showing the lowest error (-0.2%) at 3.5 km/h and the Fitbit Charge HR showing the highest error (26.8%) at 2 km/h. Heart rate measurements from the Fitbit Charge HR had a margin error of -3.42% ± 7.99% compared to electrocardiogram readings.
population_specificity: 22 healthy volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of robot-assisted walking training (Lokomat®) versus treadmill training with visual and auditory cues in improving motor and functional outcomes for patients with progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP).
results_summary: Both training methods significantly improved gait, balance, walking endurance, and reduced falls, with no significant differences between groups except for a slightly better improvement in total PSP Rating Scale for the treadmill group. The study concluded that Lokomat® did not provide additional benefits over treadmill-plus training in this context.
population_specificity: 24 patients with progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of oxygen therapy devices and portable ventilators on physical activity in daily life (PADL) for patients with chronic respiratory disease requiring long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) or home-based noninvasive ventilation (NIV).
results_summary: The study found that while technological advances have improved device portability, dependence on these devices may reduce mobility and impair PADL. Nocturnal NIV showed promise in improving PADL for hypercapnic patients, but more research is needed to assess equipment-related physical inactivity.
population_specificity: Stable patients with chronic respiratory disease requiring LTOT or home-based NIV.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to objectively quantify activity (steps walked) and sleep quality among hemodialysis patients in a suburban population and assess the impact of feedback on activity levels.
results_summary: Patients walked an average of 5,281 steps/day, significantly less on dialysis days, and rarely met the 10,000-step goal. Providing feedback did not increase activity, and sleep quality was poor, especially for first-shift patients.
population_specificity: Hemodialysis patients in a suburban setting (Baton Rouge, LA, USA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a VR-based rehabilitation treatment (GRAIL system) for improving walking abilities in children with acquired brain injury (ABI).
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in gross motor abilities, endurance, and daily life autonomy, along with enhanced gait symmetry and spatiotemporal parameters. The GRAIL system was effective in engaging children during rehabilitation.
population_specificity: 12 children with ABI (mean age 12.1 ± 3.8 years).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (implied by 10 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the predictive value of gait speed (walking speed) for early death in older outpatients with cancer.
results_summary: A gait speed < 0.8 m/s and a short physical performance battery (SPPB) score < 9 were significantly associated with early death within 6 months, independent of cancer site or extension. Walking tests, particularly gait speed, could serve as markers for early death to guide oncologic therapeutics.
population_specificity: Older outpatients with cancer (mean age 80.6 years, 50.5% men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of walking velocity as a clinical measure for monitoring disease activity and treatment response in chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy.
results_summary: The study found that walking velocity, along with handgrip strength, is a promising clinical measure for assessing disease activity and treatment efficacy in chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy. Ultrasonography also showed potential for diagnosing and monitoring the condition.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy who require repeated courses of intravenous immunoglobulin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how a structured physical activity program, including walking, affected depressive symptoms and quality of life in elderly individuals in nursing homes.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a significant decrease in depressive symptoms (measured by BDI) and significant improvements in quality of life (measured by SF 36) compared to controls. The results suggest that the physical activity program, which included walking, had positive effects on mental health and well-being.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged >65 years living in nursing homes.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of free walking, four days per week, as part of a 60-minute physical activity program (10 min warm-up, 20 min rhythmic exercises, 10 min cool-down).
